content.raw: `Parse()` has an output parameter with the data in std::string format. The return value will tell you if the string was successfully parsed. The server saves the string in a queue ready to be consumed by the RoboCup3ds plugin.
content.html: Parse() has an output parameter with the data in std::string format. The return value will tell you if the string was successfully parsed. The server saves the string in a queue ready to be consumed by the RoboCup3ds plugin.

content.raw:
The effector messages that a agent sends to the server can be found in the following link: http://simspark.sourceforge.net/wiki/index.php/Effectors. Each message has different attributes. So I have two ideas for its data structure:

1st idea: Following the current implementation of the parser, we have different data structures for each message types, for example class InitMsg has been implemented for the "init message" (Its attribute are "string rsgName" and "int robotType"). We also have implemented an interface to access its values. 
Some where in simulator we should also handle the situation that the agent can send to messages, even in Simspark, if the agent does not send an effector of the joints, the simulator will execute its previous actions. In current version of the parser, The parser keep its previous state by using singleton call. In this case, if we pass a parse() method to the server class. I think we don't need its return since it will update and keep the parser class state. 

2nd idea: We will consider only the functionality of the parser class, it is simpler and we can use your proposed architecture. we can use map<string , string> for the out-put of the parser method. Here is the example of the input and output of the parser:

S_expression sample: (he1 -10)... (init (unum 1) (teamname FCPOpp))... ( beam 1 0 0)
Out_Put: {("he1", "-10"), ("init_unum", "1"), ( "init_teamname", "FCPOpp"), ("beam_x", "1"), ("beam_y", "2"), ("beam_y", "3")}

Then , we should interpret the results out side of the parser class.

Let me know your opinion or if you have any other idea ? :)

We also have implemented an interface to access its values. 2nd idea: We will consider only the functionality of the parser class, it is simpler and we can use your proposed architecture. we can use map<string , string> for the out-put of the parser method. Here is the example of the input and output of the parser:

S_expression sample: (he1 -10)... (init (unum 1) (teamname FCPOpp))... ( beam 1 0 0) Out_Put: {("he1", "-10"), ("init_unum", "1"), ( "init_teamname", "FCPOpp"), ("beam_x", "1"), ("beam_y", "2"), ("beam_y", "3")}

Then , we should interpret the results out side of the parser class.

Let me know your opinion or if you have any other idea ? :)

content.raw:
Hi Nima, 

We took a look at how the agents are sending out messages to the server and it is in the following format:

```
#!c++

x"(...)...(...)"

Here is an actual example:
348"(beam -14.5 0 0)(he1 0.259807)(he2 -2.8381)(lae1 -3.02396)(lae2 0.58819)(lae3 -2.65155)(lae4 -0.56844)(rae1 -3.02396)(rae2 -0.548179)(rae3 2.65155)(rae4 0.56844)(lle1 0)(lle2 0.0481245)(lle3 1.40374)(lle4 -2.43462)(lle5 1.52675)(lle6 0.0722854)(lle7 0)(rle1 0)(rle2 0.0487521)(rle3 1.29475)(rle4 -2.20312)(rle5 1.40424)(rle6 0.0716699)(rle7 0)(syn)"
```

x is the length of all the s-expressions that come after it. So if the s-expressions after it is 348 characters long, then x is equal to 348. Furthermore, x is an unsigned int that is in network endian format. You have to first convert x to unsigned int, then call ntohl(x) to convert it to the proper host endian format. It is important to note that x is not a valid ascii character (it is sizeof(unsigned int) or usually 4 bytes long), but the rest of the message is. 

For the parser, it should have the following public function which the server can call: 

```
#!c++

bool Parser::parse(char* _msg, size_t _len);
```
The server will provide a char array, as well as the number of bytes that is contained in it. Parse() will examine the first sizeof(unsigned int) bytes of _msg, extract x from it, and if _len == x + sizeof(unsigned int), then it should use the s-expression library to parse all the remaining bytes. The Parser class should also have some member data structures to hold the information after they are parsed. For example, there should be a map<std::string, double> that holds the name and velocity information for the hinge joints of the nao. The function returns true when parsing is successful and all the member data structures are filled.
content.html:
Hi Nima,

We took a look at how the agents are sending out messages to the server and it is in the following format:

x"(...)...(...)"

Here is an actual example:
348"(beam -14.5 0 0)(he1 0.259807)(he2 -2.8381)(lae1 -3.02396)(lae2 0.58819)(lae3 -2.65155)(lae4 -0.56844)(rae1 -3.02396)(rae2 -0.548179)(rae3 2.65155)(rae4 0.56844)(lle1 0)(lle2 0.0481245)(lle3 1.40374)(lle4 -2.43462)(lle5 1.52675)(lle6 0.0722854)(lle7 0)(rle1 0)(rle2 0.0487521)(rle3 1.29475)(rle4 -2.20312)(rle5 1.40424)(rle6 0.0716699)(rle7 0)(syn)"

x is the length of all the s-expressions that come after it. So if the s-expressions after it is 348 characters long, then x is equal to 348. Furthermore, x is an unsigned int that is in network endian format. You have to first convert x to unsigned int, then call ntohl(x) to convert it to the proper host endian format. It is important to note that x is not a valid ascii character (it is sizeof(unsigned int) or usually 4 bytes long), but the rest of the message is.

For the parser, it should have the following public function which the server can call: 

bool Parser::parse(char* _msg, size_t _len);

The server will provide a char array, as well as the number of bytes that is contained in it. Parse() will examine the first sizeof(unsigned int) bytes of _msg, extract x from it, and if _len == x + sizeof(unsigned int), then it should use the s-expression library to parse all the remaining bytes. The Parser class should also have some member data structures to hold the information after they are parsed. For example, there should be a map<std::string, double> that holds the name and velocity information for the hinge joints of the nao. The function returns true when parsing is successful and all the member data structures are filled.

Hi Jason, I checked our team's code, you are right, in the beginning of each message we added the length of S-expressions, I will use the following code for testing the parser in the client part of the Parser_test.cc in order to emulate the real agent.

bool send(const string& msg) {

char* out = (char*) msg.c_str();
strcpy(mBuffer + 4, out);
unsigned int len = strlen(out) + 1;
unsigned int netlen = htonl(len);
memcpy(mBuffer, &netlen, 4);
    int ret = write(socketfd, mBuffer, len + 4);
fsync(sock.socketfd);

return ret;

}

Finally map<std::string, double> will be used for parsing the joints command, I will use other structure that has already been developed in "ActionParser" branch to be used in parsing other messages such as Init message and scene Message.

content.raw:
And just one more detail: After the length of the message field, there might be multiple s-expressions, not only one. So, in Jason's original example, 348 is the size in bytes of the message that the agent sends but inside that payload there are several s-expressions.

I'm going to update the server soon.

content.raw:
![server architecture.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/A9ekGz/images/2822619674-server_architecture.png)

### Legend: ###

**[Grey box]** 

RobocupPlugin: This is the master object of the plugin that creates all the other objects. It is the only object that has access to the gazebo world model. It will call the update functions of its member objects and also update the gazebo world model accordingly

**[Arrows]**

Arrows with square ends indicate that the object it is pointing to is a non-pointer member variable.

Arrows with round ends indicate that the object it is pointing to is a pointer member variable.

Arrows with dashed lines indicate a pointer to another object's method.

**[Block with dashed lines]** Gazebo world object: This is an external object that the plugin has a pointer to.

**[Colored blocks with solid lines: Each of these are an object that exists as members of the RobocupPlugin]**

GameState: This object keeps track of the state of the game and rule violations and an update method to do that. It has two important member objects: Agents and Teams. 

Perceptor: This object fills in the Agent Percept container with the update method. It also is responsible for sending a s-expression string to the server using the send method.

Effector: This object parses any s-expression sent by the server using the onconnect callback. It is reponsible for updating Agent Action container via its update method and keep track of which agent id is associated with socket id.

Server: The server manages connections from the client. When it receives data on a tcp socket, it calls the onconnect method in the Effector object. When the Perceptor finishes updating, it calls the send method and the server sends the data back to the client through the socket.

Agent Action/Percept: These are simply container classes for various perception and effector information. They do not have any methods. Each Agent object has an agent action and agent percept object
content.html:
Legend:

[Grey box]

RobocupPlugin: This is the master object of the plugin that creates all the other objects. It is the only object that has access to the gazebo world model. It will call the update functions of its member objects and also update the gazebo world model accordingly

[Arrows]

Arrows with square ends indicate that the object it is pointing to is a non-pointer member variable.

Arrows with round ends indicate that the object it is pointing to is a pointer member variable.

Arrows with dashed lines indicate a pointer to another object's method.

[Block with dashed lines] Gazebo world object: This is an external object that the plugin has a pointer to.

[Colored blocks with solid lines: Each of these are an object that exists as members of the RobocupPlugin]

GameState: This object keeps track of the state of the game and rule violations and an update method to do that. It has two important member objects: Agents and Teams.

Perceptor: This object fills in the Agent Percept container with the update method. It also is responsible for sending a s-expression string to the server using the send method.

Effector: This object parses any s-expression sent by the server using the onconnect callback. It is reponsible for updating Agent Action container via its update method and keep track of which agent id is associated with socket id.

Server: The server manages connections from the client. When it receives data on a tcp socket, it calls the onconnect method in the Effector object. When the Perceptor finishes updating, it calls the send method and the server sends the data back to the client through the socket.

Agent Action/Percept: These are simply container classes for various perception and effector information. They do not have any methods. Each Agent object has an agent action and agent percept object

Hi, this block diagram is great :) I am developing the code of the effector_box in nima_ActionParser branch. The code is using the new server architecture, thus I think it is following the proposed diagram. Currently Some modules of Effector_box  should be improved and also should be tested in different conditions (the new Parser_Test is not ready yet).

Some part of the diagram is not very clear to me: 

1- Which block will update socket_ID in GameState_box, I think it is Server? (line directly from server to gameState)

2- In the update part of the effector_box, we want to have the latest value of effectors or only we want to have effectors values in the current cycle? for each simulation cycle we will have different effectors number. If the answer is the first one we should have updating flag strategy.  

3- I think, in the preceptor code we want to have say and hear protocol? effector_box now is not processing the information of the say effector, I can add it, it is a bit tricky , because , sometimes agents send some invalid character in their say commands that cause crashes in s-expression library. even in the competition, now we have some crash in server because of that :D

content.raw:
1- The server should tell the effector what the socket id is via the onconnect callback. The effector will then access the gamestate object, create a new agent by calling the AddAgent method and then associate that new agent (using the AgentId type, which is defined in Agent.hh) with the socket id. When the ondisconnect callback is called, the effector will also remove the agent from gamestate by calling the RemoveAgent method

2- We just need the effector values sent in the current cycle.

3- The effector should update the AgentSay member variable in gamestate when it receives a say message. The perceptor will handle sending the hear message back to the server.

The effector will then access the gamestate object, create a new agent by calling the AddAgent method and then associate that new agent (using the AgentId type, which is defined in Agent.hh) with the socket id. When the ondisconnect callback is called, the effector will also remove the agent from gamestate by calling the RemoveAgent method

2- We just need the effector values sent in the current cycle.

3- The effector should update the AgentSay member variable in gamestate when it receives a say message. The perceptor will handle sending the hear message back to the server.

@jasonzliang , could you describe each block in a few words? Nothing too fancy, just a general description for us to have a better idea of what each block means.

content.raw:
Thanks for the quick update. A few considerations before you start making a new diagram:

* Shouldn't the `Gazebo World Model` be outside of the plugin, and the plugin has a pointer to it? (instead of a dashed box)

* Still related to my previous comment, it would be nice to portray the clients from outside connecting to the Server like in Carlos's Server description.

* If `Agent` and `Team` are members of `GameState`, shouldn't they be outside of it and connected with a square arrow? Alternatively, `AgentPercept` and `AgentActions` could be boxes inside `Agent`. Does this make sense?

* The relation between the `Server`, the `Perceptor` and the `AgentPercept` is not very clear to me. `Perceptor` will separately fill the `GameState::Agent::AgentPercept` and send it to the clients via the `Server`, right? Since the `Agent` has the `SocketID`, wouldn't it make more sense to follow this path: `Perceptor -> GameState::Agent::AgentPercept -> Server::Send` ? And where do the outgoing s-expressions get created?

* If the `Effector` is responsible for parsing the incoming s-expressions, where does the `SocketParser` go? Wouldn't it be better to keep all s-expression outside of the `Effector` class so if maybe in the future we change the type of communication we can keep the same interface with the `Effector`? Or did I get something wrong here?

* Maybe this is something which you've already decided with @caguero , but I'm not sure why it is the `Effector`'s responsibility to keep track of `SocketIDs`, since these will should be needed by the `Perceptor` as well, right? Maybe I'm misunderstanding the role of the `SocketParser`.
content.html:
Thanks for the quick update. A few considerations before you start making a new diagram:

  • Shouldn't the Gazebo World Model be outside of the plugin, and the plugin has a pointer to it? (instead of a dashed box)

  • Still related to my previous comment, it would be nice to portray the clients from outside connecting to the Server like in Carlos's Server description.

  • If Agent and Team are members of GameState, shouldn't they be outside of it and connected with a square arrow? Alternatively, AgentPercept and AgentActions could be boxes inside Agent. Does this make sense?

  • The relation between the Server, the Perceptor and the AgentPercept is not very clear to me. Perceptor will separately fill the GameState::Agent::AgentPercept and send it to the clients via the Server, right? Since the Agent has the SocketID, wouldn't it make more sense to follow this path: Perceptor -> GameState::Agent::AgentPercept -> Server::Send ? And where do the outgoing s-expressions get created?

  • If the Effector is responsible for parsing the incoming s-expressions, where does the SocketParser go? Wouldn't it be better to keep all s-expression outside of the Effector class so if maybe in the future we change the type of communication we can keep the same interface with the Effector? Or did I get something wrong here?

  • Maybe this is something which you've already decided with @caguero , but I'm not sure why it is the Effector's responsibility to keep track of SocketIDs, since these will should be needed by the Perceptor as well, right? Maybe I'm misunderstanding the role of the SocketParser.

content.raw:
1) The dashed box is to indicate that it is a pointer to a non member variable of the plugin.

2) I have updated the diagram to reflect the actual architecture for Agent and Team.

3) The socket ids will be kept in the agent object itself, it is the Effector class that will set them.

4) The Effector class can inherit from SocketParser and implement its interface.

5) The socket ids will be kept track by the Agent object
content.html:

2) I have updated the diagram to reflect the actual architecture for Agent and Team.

3) The socket ids will be kept in the agent object itself, it is the Effector class that will set them.

4) The Effector class can inherit from SocketParser and implement its interface.

5) The socket ids will be kept track by the Agent object

content.raw: Not sure if it's a good idea, but maybe we could write `::write()` to make it clear this is a system call? (I'm not sure what I'm talking about though, my first guess was that this was `std`. I just googled it a bit now but I might be talking crazy.)
content.html: Not sure if it's a good idea, but maybe we could write ::write() to make it clear this is a system call? (I'm not sure what I'm talking about though, my first guess was that this was std. I just googled it a bit now but I might be talking crazy.)

As far as I know the :: prefix is for specifying a global scope. Let's say you have something like this:

void Send()
{
  ...
}

class MyClass
{
  void Send()
  {
    ...
  }

  void F1()
  {
    ::Send();
  }   

  void F2()
  {
    Send()
  }
};

MyClass obj;

// This method is executing the global Send() function.
obj.F1();

// This method is executing the Send() member function.
obj.F2();

So, not sure about using it here unless there's a conflict with other send() method.

content.raw: Here , the message sent by the server to the client have been tested. I could not find any test procedure that the parser in server side is tested by using the socket assigned for the new client. (I could not implement the proposed test procedure)
content.html: Here , the message sent by the server to the client have been tested. I could not find any test procedure that the parser in server side is tested by using the socket assigned for the new client. (I could not implement the proposed test procedure)

You can see an example of this in the NewClient test. When the server is instantiated we pass in a parser instance as an argument. This parser is an instance of TrivialSocketParser that I wrote for the test. The parse() method of this class is automatically executed when there's activity on the socket. If you look at the parse() method you can see that there's a line: 

EXPECT_EQ(std::string(buffer), content);

that verifies the data received from the client.

content.raw:
I have updated the server architecture slightly. Nima you should note that there is a container class which you need to put the updated effector information into, namely the agent actions class. The effector class should have a pointer to GameState object, which in turn has Agent objects, which in turn has the Agent Action objects. You can take a look at the interface for gamestate and agents here: 

[#!/osrf/robocup3ds/src/eaf5981a5c336ea6f004f7f0296876268cac94fd/include/robocup3ds/Agent.hh?at=jliang_model](#!/osrf/robocup3ds/src/eaf5981a5c336ea6f004f7f0296876268cac94fd/include/robocup3ds/Agent.hh?at=jliang_model)
